title: 103_hr629
content:
The Act titled "Improvement of Information Access Act of 1993" is cited as the short title. The Congress recognizes the importance of a well-informed citizenry, access to government information, and the use of modern technology for citizens' benefit. Government information is considered a national resource and valuable economic asset. Government information is a valuable economic asset that belongs to the public. Taxpayers should not have to pay excessive fees for accessing information they funded. Federal agencies make it difficult for citizens to provide feedback on information policies, leading to a lack of consideration for public interests. Federal agencies are slow in developing standards for record formats and software query structures, hindering access to government information. Many agencies do not provide timely access to information at reasonable costs. Improved public access to government information is addressed in a new chapter added to Title 44 of the United States Code, focusing on information dissemination policies and practices. The new chapter in Title 44 of the United States Code addresses public access to government information by requiring executive departments to annually report their information dissemination policies and practices, including plans for new products and services. The new chapter in Title 44 of the United States Code requires executive departments to report on efforts to develop standards for information accessibility, create comprehensive indexes, and provide methods for public access to information. The new chapter in Title 44 of the United States Code requires executive departments to report on information accessibility, indexes, and public access methods, including protecting access to obsolete records and public feedback responses. The new chapter in Title 44 of the United States Code mandates that departments, military departments, and independent establishments must publish a notice in the Federal Register and other channels to inform users about the availability of reports and allow a 90-day period for public comments on their information dissemination policies and practices. This includes feedback on the types of information collected and disseminated. The new chapter in Title 44 of the United States Code requires departments and independent establishments to publish a notice in the Federal Register informing the public about their information dissemination policies. Public comments on the types of information collected, methods of storage and dissemination, pricing, and information quality must be made available for inspection. The new chapter in Title 44 of the United States Code mandates agencies to engage in dialogue with the public through hearings and forums on information dissemination policies. Agencies must also provide a 120-day notice before discontinuing an information product or service. Each agency must provide a 120-day notice for public comments before discontinuing an information product or service. They should disseminate information through various channels to ensure public access to government information. The government must disseminate information in a timely and reliable manner, store information in standardized formats, and use distribution channels for free or low-cost public access. Agencies cannot charge depository libraries for distributing information products unless authorized by statute. The government must distribute information products and services without charging more than the incremental cost, or any royalty fees for redissemination. The Archivist of the United States and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will issue guidelines jointly. The National Institute of Standards and Technology, in collaboration with other agencies, will establish model performance standards for providing public access to records. These standards will include timelines for agencies to mail copies of various public documents upon request. SEC. 4. STANDARDS FOR ACCESS TO PUBLIC RECORDS.

The Archivist of the United States and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will issue model performance standards for providing access to agency records under section 4101(f) of title 44, United States Code within one year of the enactment of this Act.
